title: [Pipeline Sec - GraphQL migration]: Create GraphQL version of `vulnerability_details.vue`
description:
## What ❓

We want to create a new `vulnerability_details.vue` component, which will be used for the GraphQL versions of the pipeline tab's modal and the vulnerability details page.

## Why ℹ️

The current [`vulnerability_details.vue`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vulnerabilities/components/vulnerability_details.vue) is set up to work with [data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/serializers/vulnerabilities/finding_entity.rb#L43) that is [injected via HAML](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/views/projects/security/vulnerabilities/show.html.haml). 

The data-structure that will be coming from [GraphQL is different](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/337873#note_1042796388) to that, so we would have the following options:

1. Add to the current details component, so it supports both HAML and GraphQL data.
2. Transform either the HAML- or GraphQL data so the component gets a normalized data structure.
3. Create a new component that will eventually replace the current one.

After some brainstorming it was concluded that approach `3` might be the best solution, since it will allow us to:

* Work on the GraphQL migration behind a feature flag, without any danger of breaking the feature on production. This also means less manual testing efforts while working on it.
* Deprecate the current component (via renaming it and including a `_deprecated` or `_legacy` suffix)
* Create a clean, uncluttered component that - once the migration has been completed - can be used as is, without any modification to it
* It let's us remove some technical debt (for example remove the `.md` class, which currently wraps the data-listing and causes some styling issues)
* ... I am sure I am missing some - feel free to add to this :slight_smile: 

Potential drawbacks:

* Might create a bit of maintenance overhead, since we will need to support the HAML  version until the GraphQL migration has been completed (for both the pipeline and details page)
* Possible code duplication until the legacy component (and specs) are removed
* ... I am sure I am missing some - feel free to add to this :slight_smile:

title: BE: Allow sorting by health status in the issue list
description:
<!-- This template is a great use for issues that are feature::additions or technical tasks for larger issues.-->

### Proposal

Allow sorting by health status in the issue list. This would be useful for users that want to see all issues but review the ones that are not "healthy" first.

The ordering should follow the following behaviour:

* When ascending, healthy issues will be shown first (on track, needs attention, at risk).
* When descending, unhealthy issues will be shown first (at risk, needs attention, on track).
* Issues without a health status will always be shown last.

This issue tracks the ~backend work only and the ~frontend work will be completed via https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/377841.

title: compile-production-assets has large spread in duration percentiles
description:
## Challenge

`compile-production-assets` is on the critical path of Frontend pipelines and has a P50 and P90 duration that ranges from 15 minutes to 28 minutes which indicates that the cache is not rebuilt when needed. Compared to `compile-test-assets` the P50 to P90 range is 6 to 8 minutes

![image](/uploads/8aef4631514f3d7b415a03cd10d52d32/image.png)

Is there a more effective way of re-building the cache to close the gap?

### Efforts

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96292
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96403
- In progress: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96297

title: Create Jitsu attributes application settings
description:
## Overview

We need to provide a way for GitLab instance adminstrators to add Jitsu tracking data to enable its use with the analytics stack.

## Technical proposal

* Add two new application settings to GitLab. `jitsu_host` and `jitsu_js_api_token`. Both of these should be optional and defaulted to `nil`.
* Create a new feature flag `dogfood_analytics_jitsu` which must be `default off` and scoped to individual users.
* When both of the application settings are set, and the feature flag is enabled for `current_user`, add `jitsu_host` to the content security policy. (`ApplicationController#L114`)
* When both of the application settings are set, and the feature flag is enabled for `current_user`, pass settings to `window.gon` for ~frontend use like we do for Sentry: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/gon_helper.rb#L19

## Privacy concerns

* Because we'll be blocking the connection unless both settings are defined **and** the feature flag is enabled for a specific group of users, we minimize the concern that users will be tracked unless they specifically opt in.

title: In-operator optimization support for JOINs
description:
The [in-operator optimization](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/database/efficient_in_operator_queries.html) works only when the `ORDER BY` columns are located in the same table as defined in the `FROM` clause. 

We have a few use-cases where the in-operator optimization might help improving the performance of database queries where the `ORDER BY` columns are coming from a JOIN-ed relation. 

Related thread with some ideas: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93080#note_1053812747

Task: Extend the in-operator optimization code to support [custom `Order` definitions](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/database/keyset_pagination.html#complex-order-configuration) on `JOIN-ed` columns.

- Apply the diffs mentioned in the [thread](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93080#note_1053812747)
- At least three test cases are needed in the query builder test (`spec/lib/gitlab/pagination/keyset/in_operator_optimization/query_builder_spec.rb`)
  - `ORDER BY from_table.column1 ASC, joined_table.column2 ASC`
  - `ORDER BY from_table.column1 ASC, joined_table.column2 DESC`
  - `ORDER BY joined_table.column1 ASC, from_table.column2 ASC` where `joined_table.columnt1` is nullable
- Add documentation

title: Browser issue "A web page is slowing down your browser" while rendering repository file listing
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

A customer reported problems loading a repository file list.  GitLab members can read more in the [ticket](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/309389).

The problem seems to relate to rendering JSON returned by `/namespace/repo/-/refs/path/to/directory?format=json&offset=xxx`

This issue is a request for help from ~"group::source code" - I don't know how to debug this further.

### Steps to reproduce

- Customer reported the issue at 14.10.5 after upgrading from 14.2
- I understand [14.3 changed](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/69274) how file listings from Git repos are loaded by the GitLab WebUI:
  - A graphql query loads the file listing for the page
  - The commit details are then loaded in batches of 25
- Looking at the HAR output, for the offsets `0`, `25`, `50`, `75`, `100`, `125`:
  - No more batches load, but there are 200 files, so there should be more batches (`150` is definitely valid, it's attached to the ticket).
  - Each loads from the backend fairly quickly. 600ms is the longest, but most are 125-200ms, the last two to load are 199ms and 127ms.  I don't think it's a backend problem (more below).
  - The time delays **between** requesting each JSON batch are fairly consistent for the first five batches.
  - However, between batches `100` and `125` (the last one) ~21 seconds elapses.
  - See screenshot from HAR file, which is supplied on the ticket July 28th.
    - Note the very long elapsed time between batches 100 and 125, and that batch 150 is not requested.
    - My guess is that rendering batch 125 triggers the browser warning.

![HAR-time-elapsed](/uploads/9974536b1d9e24ee2b14f926047e67b9/HAR-time-elapsed.png)

It's not a problem with pulling that JSON from the back end. 

[1] The repository is small.

- Total commit history on their main working branch is `11701`. 
- The repo shows in the UI as 67mb.
- The total number of files in the directory affected are `203`.

[2] The HAR file shows that JSON requests are quick

[3] I've generated slow backend (Gitay) performance in a test environment, and in this case, the failure on the front end is different from what the customer is seeing.

- The browser is happy to wait for the (max) 30 seconds that Workhorse/Rails are prepared to wait for Gitaly to return the data.
- If the JSON is returned in time, it's sent to the browser.
- If the 30 second timeout is reached, a 500 is sent to the browser, and the frontend code stops trying to load the page;  no more batches are requested.

- If the JSON is returned in time, it's sent to the browser.
I tested this using https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab project, cloned to a self-managed instance.  Some of the directories of large files in our code base take a long time (on my slow test system) to load the commit batches as JSON from Gitaly, and I was able to exceed the 30 second timeout.

We have the raw JSON for the file commits on the ticket (August 10th).  I asked them to download all the batches up to where it fails, and beyond.  I've looked at the json, and by eye I can't see any problems with it.  I was wondering if there might be some unexpected data being returned by the backend.  If this is the case, it's not obvious.

- Their activities in this particular directory in the repository are primary via the GitLab web interface.
- The files here are managed by an operational team that aren't developers, and so don't use the Git CLI.

related issues:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/361004  (they're not using codeowners)
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333669 is currently scheduled for %"15.4" and might help here

### Example Project

<!-- If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic 
behavior, and link to it here in the bug report. If you are using an older version of GitLab, this 
will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version. -->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Part way through loading and rendering the page, the browser reports "A web page is slowing down your browser, what would you like to do?"

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Rendering the JSON data is quick, and page load completes.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

<!-- Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code
 as it's tough to read otherwise. -->

### Output of checks

<!-- If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com -->

#### Results of GitLab environment info

Self managed 14.10.5

### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

title: Require conversation resolution before merging
description:
## Problem to solve

Protected branches in GitLab are implemented differently than in GitHub. For example, in GitHub there are some protected rules that you can apply on one or a few branches that match an expression, while those rules exist in GitLab as a general project settings for all branches. In this issue we make the mapping, so if a protected rule is defined in GH, and similar rule exists in GitLab general settings, we will configure the migrated GitLab project with this rule as a general settings, and this rule will be applied to all branches.

## Purposed solution

```gherkin
 Scenario: "Require conversation resolution before merging"
    Given "Require conversation resolution" before merging is defined as a branch protected rule in GitHub
    When a user imports this repository to GitLab
    Then the settings All threads must be resolved in the GitLab project settings will be enabled 
```

Add documentation of this mapping.

## Technical details

Get default branch protection rule from [Github API](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/branches/branch-protection#get-branch-protection). Look at `required_conversation_resolution` value and put it into projects `only_allow_merge_if_all_discussions_are_resolved` attr.

epic.title: Import GitHub rules for protected branches

title: Approval rules using subgroups don't work after feature flag release
description:
### Summary

:wave: It appears the rollout of #366741+ (`:subgroups_approval_rules`) is impacting customers that utilise subgroups in merge request approval rules. Given this can break approval rules I've marked it as confidential until the group confirms it can be released as public information.

I've assigned @vyaklushin for review of this issue to confirm it is related to the feature.

Originally reported in [this ticket](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/316631), a customer has indicated approval rules aren't working correctly. From further examination it was found they extensively use subgroups in their approval rules.

We've taken steps to re-produce this in both SaaS and Self-managed, with the former being available to GitLab team members in [this example project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-gold/benjaminking/broken-approvals/project) and [this merge request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-gold/benjaminking/broken-approvals/project/-/merge_requests/3). For Self-managed instances, you must use GitLab 15.2 and enable the feature flag with: 

```
Feature.enable(:subgroups_approval_rules)
```
And create a new merge request to see the behaviour.

|Self-Managed (without feature flag) - GIF |Self-Managed (with feature flag) - GIF|
|--|--|
|![working](/uploads/bc38008e92a2b393d4f9c778076d38d3/working.gif)| ![broken](/uploads/e34b6b94d3b4b8de8655911b8f3314ea/broken.gif)|

### Steps to reproduce

On GitLab.com (SaaS):

You will need to have a project and subgroup to use as a group for approval rules.

1. Create a group that is linked to a Premium subscription. An easy example is a subgroup using [`gitlab-gold`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-gold) if you have access. 
1. Create a subgroup. 
2. Under the subgroup, create a project named 'Project'.
3. Under the subgroup, create another subgroup, named 'code-approvers-group'.
4. Under the 'code-approvers-group' group, create another subgroup named 'reviewers-one'

The structure should be similar to: 

Project: 
`Parent → subgroup → Project`

Group:
`Parent → subgroup → code-approvers-group → reviewers-one`

Next, create working and not working rules in the project under **Settings > General > Merge Request Approvals**

1. Working Rule

- Rule name: "Working Rule"
- Target branch: `main`
- Approvals required: 1
- Add approvers: `Parent/subgroup`

2. Not Working Rule

- Rule name: "Not Working Rule"
- Target branch: `main`
- Approvals required: 1
- Add approvers: `Parent/subgroup/code-approvers-group/reviewers-one`

Most GitLab team members can [check the settings in the example project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-gold/benjaminking/broken-approvals/project/edit).

If using Self-Managed, enable the feature flag with `Feature.enable(:subgroups_approval_rules)`, then follow the above steps.


### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-gold/benjaminking/broken-approvals

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Approval rules referencing the subgroup are not applied, with the rule marked as "complete", and not showing group members: 

![image](/uploads/81fc72ec2e6faaaa4af287ae734faa55/image.png)

Additionally, the label for the approvals shows 2 approvals are required for the *working* rule: 

![image](/uploads/6033bb007e2b631769f8d008f8fc449b/image.png)

### Workaround

The current workaround appears to be to set `Prevent editing approval rules in merge requests`, which stops this from happening during MR creation.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The approval rule referencing the subgroup should be applied, to ensure there is a level of oversight on approvals for merging code.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

Provided above where applicable :smile:

epic.title: Approval rules configuration

title: GitHub Importer: API for bulk import of personal gists to personal snippets
description:
### Release notes

With GitHub Importer, you could import GitHub repositories to GitLab, however there was no possibility to import gists as well. Now you can use a new public API endpoint to bulk-import your [personal gists](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/gists/gists#list-gists-for-the-authenticated-user) into [your personal GitLab Snippets](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/snippets.html#create-snippets) visible on [Snippets Dashboard](https://gitlab.com/dashboard/snippets).

### Problem to solve

We can import repos from GitHub, but for a more complete migration away from GitHub, we would need to have a way to import GitHub Gists as well.

With the release of [Snippets with multiple Files](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/14340), it is now possible to migrate GitHub Gists (up to 10 files) directly into GitLab Snippets. As we haven't had any requests to increase that limit in the product and allow snippets to have more files, we won't try to make that possible with import either.

### Proposal

Create a public API for a bulk import of personal gists [created by the person](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/gists/gists#list-gists-for-the-authenticated-user) into [their personal GitLab Snippets](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/snippets.html#create-snippets) visible on [Snippets Dashboard](https://gitlab.com/dashboard/snippets):

* public gists become public visibility level snippets
* secret gists become private visibility level snippets.

### Technical details 

If gist description is present, we use it as the snippet title (attention: Gist description has a limit of 256, while the snippet's title can be up to 255).

If gist description is missing we use the file name (filename of the first file, if there are multiple files) as a snippet title.

In case of gists with multiple files, in the first iteration we:

* skip the import of anything larger than 10 files
* log an error when a gist import has to be skipped in a way we can query the frequency
* document this limit and encourage customers to manually migrate these rare gists over to projects.

No import of gists comments, only gists description and files.

epic.title: Import GitHub Gists as GitLab Snippets

title: Add members.member_namespace_id foreign key constraint validate: true
description:
Now that we have a foreign key constraint `NOT VALID` [in the database](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93240) and there are [no more `NULL` `members.member_namespace_id` rows](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/365028), [we need to switch the constraint to valid](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/database/add_foreign_key_to_existing_column.html#validate-the-foreign-key).

This needs to be released at least one release after https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/349640

title: Flaky test ShouldReturnRequestCountAndSumResponseSize
description:
### Problem

The unit test `ShouldReturnRequestCountAndSumResponseSize` sometimes fails when run on multi-CPU runners.

- Example job: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/api-fuzzing-src/-/jobs/2810807453

It's possible the test itself is broken. It doesn't appear to take into consideration changes to the path of the URL.

description:
Documentation for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/335931 feature.

Current draft MR: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93491

title: Add has_epic field to IssueType on GraphQL
description:
With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/371081 we are going to allow  
epics having child issues from different group hierarchies.  

From the issue view, for a user that does not have access to the parent epic, we  
need to display some kind of message/placeholder pointing out that the issue belongs to 
an epic but it is not readable. To achieve this on frontend we need a new field on Graphql, `has_epic`  
which returns true if the parent epic is present.

title: Maintainer can leak Github access tokens by changing integration URL (even after 15.2.1 patch)
description:
**[HackerOne report #1656722](https://hackerone.com/reports/1656722)** by `joaxcar` on 2022-08-01, assigned to `GitLab Team`:

[Report](#report) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

#####  Summary

In the 15.2.1 patch there was a fix for my reports that are bundled in the report https://hackerone.com/reports/1557992

The patch failed to fix at least one integration, the Github one. This integration still allows for changing the URL and leaking the configured access token.

This makes it possible for a malicious user(maintainer) to change the server to a user controlled server, where the attacker can then extract the token. The attacker needs maintainer access to the project, but should nevertheless not have access to the configured access token. The impact is the same as for my previous reports. I did mention this issue in the original report but I guess it slipped through.

#####  Steps to reproduce

Make sure to have a webhook server where you can see incoming requests. I use https://webhook.site for my tests

You will need to generate a project with mirrored repository from Github for the integration to be enabled. So I will first describe that.

1. Log in to github.com (note: GITHUB)  
2. Create a repository, name it anything  
3. Create an API token with "repo" scope, https://github.com/settings/tokens

Then on GITLAB:

1. Create two users `victim` and `attacker`  
2. Log in as `victim`, and create a new project. Make sure to UNCHECK "initialize with README"  
3. Go to https://gitlab.com/GROUPNAME/PROJECTNAME/-/project_members  
4. Invite `attacker` as a maintainer to the project  
5. Go to https://gitlab.com/GROUPNAME/PROJECTNAME/-/settings/repository and expand "Mirroring repositories""  
6.  Configure both a PUSH and a PULL mirroring, enter URL as https://USERNAME@github.com/REPOPATH and the generated API token as password. Make sure to check all boxes (I dont know what is needed, check everything)  
7. Now go to https://gitlab.com/GROUPNAME/PROJECTNAME/-/settings/integrations/github/edit  
8. fill in the access token `HIDDEN_TOKEN` and GitHub repo https://github.com/anything/anything  
9. Click save, the token field should turn empty  
10. Log in with `attacker`   
11. Go to https://gitlab.com/GROUPNAME/PROJECTNAME/-/settings/integrations/github/edit  
12. Enter a new value for server URL using the catch server  
13. Click `Test settings`  
14. Go to the catch server and see that a request have been received with the token in plain text

If the "Test settings" button is missing, there is something wrong with the repo mirroring.

#####  Impact

User with maintainer access can leak the configured GitHub access token. This token is supposed to be hidden and will give the attacker access to the GitHub API as the victim user.


#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?

Changing server URL does not reset the previous access token

#####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?

When the server URL changes, the token should be deleted

#####  Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

####  Impact

Leakage of sensitive tokens to other maintainers. Potentially giving the attacker access to external systems

####  Impact

Leakage of sensitive tokens to other maintainers. Potentially giving the attacker access to external systems


[reproducibility information]: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/security/#reproducibility-on-security-issues

title: Allow epics to have child issues from different group hierarchies
description:
In order to complete https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8294#proposal we need to remove model and service  
validations allowing epics having child issues from different group hierarchies.  

There is a small POC that points out which validations should be removed https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/95075.  

It is also important to double-check if any information could leak to unauthorized users. There is a small
checklist that can be used as inspiration https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370541

epic.title: Epics can have child issues from different group hierarchies

title: Navigating back to Changes doesn't work if you use discussions navigation
description: ## Steps to reproduce 1. Open any MR that you own with none of the discussion threads related to the code 2. Go to Changes tab 3. Click on `Next` or `Previous` button (), you should be redirected to the Overview tab 4. Click on a `Back` button in your browser Expectation: you should be brought back to the Changes tab right where you left off Reality: you are brought to the page where you were before going to the Changes tab or simply stay on the Overview tab

title: Do not show issue parent epic properties to an unauthorized user when exporting a project
description:
Part of the work to allow [cross-group epic/issues linking](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8294#proposal).  

If we remove model/service validations to allow epic to have child issues from different 
group hierarchies we could start leaking unauthorized epic information if the user does not have access
to the epic group.

All the parent epic properties are exposed in the JSON file that contains issue fields within the project export.

epic.title: Epics can have child issues from different group hierarchies

title: Prevent leaking epic title to unauthorized users when exporting child issue as CSV
description:
Part of the work to allow [cross-group epic/issues linking](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8294#proposal).  
r
If we remove model/service validations to allow epic to have child issues from different 
group hierarchies we could start leaking unauthorized epic information when exporting issues on the CSV file if the user does not have access to the epic group. 

Before removing validations we need to verify if the user can read parent epic on `Issues::ExportCsvService` and if not, remove epic title from the csv.

epic.title: Epics can have child issues from different group hierarchies

title: Fix parent groups authorization for member of child groups that has projects
description:
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93601 introduced a new way
to fetch epics on big group hierarchies for users with guest access or lower, but it 
also introduced a problem.  

How to reproduce:  

1. Create a private Group A   
2. Add a subgroup B
3. Add an user X to subgroup B
4. Add a project Y to subgroup B

After **step 4** user X should be able to read group A because subgroup B has a project, but now it does not happen. 

If the user has direct authorization on Project Y then it will still behave as before, in this case, we are covered.

This is an old authorization inconsistency described at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/36658 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/340421, but anyway previous behavior should be restored.

title: Clicking back to MR Overview tab doesn't change page URL
description:
## Steps to reproduce

1. Open any MR with some changes
2. Click on Changes tab
3. Clink on any line to get an anchor link in the page URL
4. Click on Overview tab

Expected: URL should not contain `/diff#...` part

Reality: URL still contains `/diff#...` part

title: Regression - Gitlab release evidence not being collected if release is created via UI
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

(Summarize the bug encountered concisely)
 
Users reported a regression where Release evidence is not generated consistently when you create a release from a tag in the UI.

### Steps to reproduce

(How one can reproduce the issue - this is very important)

1. Go to Project > Project Overview > Releases 
1. Click Create a Release button 
1. Fill out relevant release details 
1. Navigate to the created Release and see if Evidence has been collected 

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

(What actually happens)

Evidence is NOT collected 

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

(What you should see instead)

Evidence is collected 

# Implementation

- [x] Do not send `released_at` unless it is specified by the user - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/96183
- [x] Check for Release Evidence in feature spec - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/95748
- [x] Update docs to mention that `released_at` should only be specified when creating a historical or upcoming Release - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/97177

title: PoC on DORA metric configuration object
description:
## Summary

Based on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/358385

We need to provide PoC for DORA metrics configuration which allows us to alter metrics calculation behaviour. This PoC should be used for ~Dogfooding on gitlab.com itself.

## Proposal

Create a feature flag which enables alternative behaviour of DORA metrics calculation for particular project. With it enabled only MRs targeting `main` or `master` branch while calculating Lead Time For Changes metric. To reduce scope of this PoC several assumptions and simplifications has been made:

1. No data migration is supported. All old data will stay as it was before enabling feature flag and only new gathered data will be calculated with new approach. Same applies to disabling feature flag.
2. No UI for configuration is required. Hardcoded configuration should mark `main` and `master` as target branch to filter out project MRs.
3. Only project level should be supported for now. No propagation to group level is required.

/cc @blabuschagne

epic.title: DORA 4 Metrics API Support - Complete Maturity

title: POC: Helm support
description:
Build a proof of concept of Helm Chart support.

Please see the [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7938) and the [MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/-/merge_requests/727) for more information.

## Release notes

Kubernetes users can now [use the agent for Kubernetes to deploy their applications packaged in Helm charts](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/clusters/agent/gitops/helm.html). Helm is likely the most popular Kubernetes packaging tool. Until now, the agent for Kubernetes only supported vanilla Kubernetes manifest files for its GitOps workflow. Helm users had to use a CI job to render and commit the resources to benefit from the GitOps workflow. 

The current release ships with Alpha support for Helm in the agent. As Helm is a mature product, we consider the solution performant but has a few [known limitations](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/clusters/agent/gitops/helm.html#known-issues), and the API might change without prior notice. We welcome your feedback in [the related epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7938), where we discuss future improvements and next steps.

title: Compliance Framework – Update settings
description:
Brought up in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/339887#note_1067537267 we should consider to update how the Compliance frameworks are presented in the settings. Using a more dense layout, similar to how we present streamed audit events today.

| Before | After |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/78cf008458b3f165057e8fa9693d7d00/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/8ee548e1df0a91e86886d0a28c6e5a8e/image.png) |

### Implementation plan

1. Update the `Add framework` button to be `category: secondary`.
1. Update the current list of frameworks to use `table` component
   - Rename `list` Compliance components to `table`.
     - `ee/app/assets/javascripts/groups/settings/compliance_frameworks/components/list.vue`
     - `ee/app/assets/javascripts/groups/settings/compliance_frameworks/components/list_item.vue`
     - `ee/app/assets/javascripts/groups/settings/compliance_frameworks/components/list_empty_state.vue`
   - Update `list.vue` line 165 `list-item` element to use the `gl-table-lite` component here https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/docs/base-table-table-lite--default
     - Lite will be used to reduce the pagebundle payload size, as it will not use filtering etc
   - Add header column templates and appropriate i18n labels
   - Split `list_item.vue` into each of the column templates matching headers eg name, description, actions
1. Update specs and ensure running
1. Update ~documentation.

title: Introduce REST API for project transfer locations
description:
We need to expose a new REST API endpoint that

- given a project, gives us a list of groups to where the `current_user` can transfer that project to.

Endpoint will be:

```
GET /projects/:id/transfer_locations
```

title: Build an implementation plan for Container Registry active database load balancing
description:
## Context

This is part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8591. Before implementing active database load balancing, we must devise a plan and validate its feasibility. That's the purpose of this issue.

There is yet no support for the registry database on self-managed installs. We're first completing the GitLab.com upgrade/migration (https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5523). Support for self-managed will happen later (https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5521).

The ideal solution would fit both self-managed and GitLab.com use cases, but, considering that:

- There is not yet support for self-managed, so we do not have any kind of insight about usage/performance there to decide whether or not load-balancing would be beneficial a first step might be a simplified approach that fits well with the GitLab.com architecture.

## Background

On GitLab.com, the registry database is hosted on a dedicated PostgreSQL cluster (v12 at the time of writing)  comprised of a primary server and multiple replica servers. The primary and the pool of replicas sit behind separate Consul DNS names for easy discoverability and load balancing:

![image](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/uploads/2ae96e0e2a8c39923798ca8a5cf7b6f2/image.png)

## Problem

We currently support [multi-host connections](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/devel/libpq-connect.html#LIBPQ-MULTIPLE-HOSTS) for failover, but we do not support active load-balancing to send read-only queries to a read-only replica whenever possible.

For availability and performance reasons, we should be able to perform active load-balancing.

## Solution

## Implementation Plan

title: Track MR survey dismissals
description:
From https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/366561#note_1051342590.

Having the response rate of the in-product MR survey will allow us to put the responses into context and understand how well the survey is performing. For that, we want to track both renders and dismissals.

We're already charting the funnel between the 1st and 2nd questions in the [dashboard](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/1049374/Merge-request-experience-survey). If we added renders and dismissals, that would allow us to visualize the funnel as:

1. Survey shown
1. Dismissed without answering
1. Answered 1st question
1. Answered 2nd question

This issue focuses on tracking dismissals only.

epic.title: In-product survey on MRs performance

title: Ensure `environment` keyword is defined on all `deploy` jobs in documentation (batch 7)
description:
See https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8590+ for more details

### Implementation guide

Make sure that all `stage: deploy` jobs in the following documentation files are already have `environment:` keyword.

If some of them don't, then add the 

```yaml
environment: production
```

(substitute `production` to other environmens like `dev` or `staging` where it makes more sense).

```
doc/user/packages/container_registry/index.md
299:  stage: deploy

doc/user/packages/npm_registry/index.md
324:  stage: deploy

doc/user/packages/nuget_repository/index.md
399:     stage: deploy

doc/user/infrastructure/iac/mr_integration.md
140:  stage: deploy

doc/api/templates/gitlab_ci_ymls.md
138:  "content": "# This file is a template, and might need editing before it works on your project.
# To contribute improvements to CI/CD templates, please follow the Development guide at:
# https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/cicd/templates.html
# This specific template is located at:
# https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Ruby.gitlab-ci.yml

# Official language image. Look for the different tagged releases at:
# https://hub.docker.com/r/library/ruby/tags/
image: ruby:latest

# Pick zero or more services to be used on all builds.
# Only needed when using a docker container to run your tests in.
# Check out: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/services/index.html
services:
  - mysql:latest
  - redis:latest
  - postgres:latest

variables:
  POSTGRES_DB: database_name

# Cache gems in between builds
cache:
  paths:
    - vendor/ruby

# This is a basic example for a gem or script which doesn't use
# services such as redis or postgres
before_script:
  - ruby -v  # Print out ruby version for debugging
  # Uncomment next line if your rails app needs a JS runtime:
  # - apt-get update -q && apt-get install nodejs -yqq
  - bundle config set --local deployment true  # Install dependencies into ./vendor/ruby
  - bundle install -j $(nproc)

# Optional - Delete if not using `rubocop`
rubocop:
  script:
    - rubocop

rspec:
  script:
    - rspec spec

rails:
  variables:
    DATABASE_URL: "postgresql://postgres:postgres@postgres:5432/$POSTGRES_DB"
  script:
    - rails db:migrate
    - rails db:seed
    - rails test

# This deploy job uses a simple deploy flow to Heroku, other providers, e.g. AWS Elastic Beanstalk
# are supported too: https://github.com/travis-ci/dpl
deploy:
  stage: deploy
  environment: production
  script:
    - gem install dpl
    - dpl --provider=heroku --app=$HEROKU_APP_NAME --api-key=$HEROKU_PRODUCTION_KEY
"
```

title: Project storage notifications should only display for group owners
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

Currently, project-level storage notifications are displayed to all project maintainers, regardless of whether their project has excess storage usage. As an MVC, project-level storage threshold notifications should only show for group owners.

Later iteration suggestion: threshold notifications display for the project maintainers of the projects that have excess storage usage.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

View group page as a project maintainer on a group that has one or more projects near or over the project-level storage quota which is applied for repository and LFS.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->

Storage threshold notification banners display for non-owners of a group

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->

Storage threshold notification banners should only display for group owners

title: Unify redis metric aggregation definition
description:
## Background

Because Redis[metric aggregation feature](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/service_ping/implement.html#aggregated-metrics) was created before `merics yml definitions` and this caused legacy duplication and distribution of information. Event can be aggregated into metric with 3 of following ways:
1. Total metrics - already [deprecated feature](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/service_ping/implement.html#known-events-are-added-automatically-in-service-data-payload), yet still used by [some older metrics](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data_counters/hll_redis_counter.rb#L21)
2. Aggregated metrics - via yaml config files at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/master/config/metrics/aggregates and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/master/ee/config/metrics/aggregates
3. Metric yaml definition - via `option.events` 

This makes create confusing experience for developers, and makes it harder to utilize aggregation information for any downstream systems as discussed at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370462#note_1067324388

## Goal

Unify way of defining metrics aggregation, possibly remove all other methods and adjust metrics yaml definition files to be able to convey information about metrics aggregation including both redis and database sources as well as union and intersection operators (`AND` and `OR`)

## Implementation

1. Migrate remaining total metrics instrumentation to metrics yaml definitions, this work is related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368996 and can be covered by it
1. Add support for metrics aggreggation [attributes](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/service_ping/implement.html#aggregated-metrics) to metrics yaml definitions
1. Add existing aggregated metrics definitions to metrics yaml definitions
1. Change agggregated metrics implementation to read from metrics yamls definitions https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage/metrics/aggregates.rb#L10
1. Remove legacy aggregated metrics definitions
1. Add information about counted attribute to metrics yaml definition

<details><summary>Previous implementation plan</summary>
1. Migrate remaining total metrics instrumentation to metrics yaml definitions, this work is related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368996 and can be covered by it
2. Enhance metrics yaml definitions and aggregated metrics feature to use metrics yaml as source for aggregated metrics definition
   1. ~~Add support for metrics aggregation [attributes](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/service_ping/implement.html#aggregated-metrics) to metrics yaml definitions~~ moved to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/373830
   2. Add existing aggregated metrics definitions to metrics yaml definitions
   3. Change aggregated metrics implementation to read from metrics YAML definitions https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage/metrics/aggregates.rb#L10
   4. Remove legacy aggregated metrics definitions
3. Add information about counted attribute to metrics yaml definition
</details>

## Testing
Ensure related tests are passing

title: Require a pull request before merging
description:
## Problem to solve

Protected branches in GitLab are implemented differently than in GitHub. For example, in GitHub there are some protected rules that you can apply on one or a few branches that match an expression, while those rules exist in GitLab as a general project settings for all branches. In this issue we make the mapping, so if a protected rule is defined in GH, and similar rule exists in GitLab general settings, we will configure the migrated GitLab project with this rule as a general settings, and this rule will be applied to all branches.

## Purposed solution

```gherkin
Scenario: Require a pull request before merging When enabled, all commits must be made to a non-protected branch and submitted via a pull request before they can be merged into a branch that matches this rule.
    Given "Require a pull request before merging When enabled, all commits must be made to a non-protected branch and submitted via a pull request before they can be merged into a branch that matches this rule." protected rule is defined in GitHub
    When a user imports this repository to GitLab
    Then in GitLab project settings, in the Allowed to merge list, Developers + Maintainers will be selected, and in the Allowed to push list, No one will be selected.
```

## Technical details

Get branch protection rules from [Github API](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/branches/branch-protection#get-branch-protection). Look at `required_pull_request_reviews` and map it's value into `project.protected_branches.push_access_levels & project.protected_branches.merge_access_levels` associations.

**Note**: previously we decided to use the strictest set of branch protection rules (in [this issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/22650)). So, if the imported protected branch is also protected in GitLab, we will apply the strictest rule for push_access_level/merge_access_level.

[This pseudo code](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370951#note_1119576532) explains the logic of how exactly the mapping should be done here.

This _flowchart_ shows how access_levels for imported protected branch are set:
![issues_370951-push_access_level-and-merge_access_level](/uploads/529b8892d76a68df17eeb7b84f52ee5c/issues_370951-push_access_level-and-merge_access_level.jpg)

epic.title: Import GitHub rules for protected branches

title: Require signed commits
description:
## Problem to solve 

Protected branches in GitLab are implemented differently than in GitHub. For example, in GitHub there are some protected rules that you can apply on one or a few branches that match an expression, while those rules exist in GitLab as a general project settings for all branches. In this issue we make the mapping, so if a protected rule is defined in GH, and similar rule exists in GitLab general settings, we will configure the migrated GitLab project with this rule as a general settings, and this rule will be applied to all branches. 

## Purposed solution

```gherkin
Scenario: "Require signed commits"
    Given "Require signed commits" a branch protected rule in GitHub checked
    When a user imports this repository to GitLab
    Then the settings "Reject unsigned commits" in the GitLab project settings will be enabled 
```

Add documentation of this mapping.

## Technical details

Get default branch protection rule from [Github API](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/branches/branch-protection#get-branch-protection). When possible (on Premium and Ultimate GL) look at `required_signatures` and map its value into `project.push_rule` attributes.

epic.title: Import GitHub rules for protected branches

title: Scenario: "Require status checks to pass before merging"
description:
## Problem to solve

[External status checks](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/status_checks.html) are available on Ultimate only, plus currently

> The lack of a status check response does not block the merging of a merge request.

On top of technical difficulties outlined by @knockfog [below](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370948#note_1089605367) that makes it impossible to translate GitHub's "Require status checks to pass before merging" rule to projects imported into GitLab.

## Purposed solution

We should add a short note to the documentation:
- state that integrations aren't applied during import and this rule cannot be translated during import
- link to [External status checks](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/status_checks.html) 
- possibly point to "Support to allow merges to be blocked when external status checks fail is proposed in epic [&8516](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8516)" as well.

Protected branches in GitLab are implemented differently than in GitHub. For example, in GitHub there are some protected rules that you can apply on one or a few branches that match an expression, while those rules exist in GitLab as a general project settings for all branches. In this issue we make the mapping, so if a protected rule is defined in GH, and similar rule exists in GitLab general settings, we will configure the migrated GitLab project with this rule as a general settings, and this rule will be applied to all branches. 

## Purposed solution

GitHub's `"Settings" > "Branches" > "Allow force pushes" > "Everyone"` should be mapped into GitLab's `"Settings" > "Repository" > "Protected branches" > "Allowed to force push"`.

If on GitHub this setting is set as not "Everyone" but "Specify who" then we should ignore it because GitLab doesn't support this level of configuration yet. 

It's safer to add less permissions (which we do here), but in this case we need make sure the user is aware of this differences by stressing this in documentation.

```gherkin
 Scenario: "Allow force pushes" - "everyone" 
    Given "Allow force pushes" is defined in GitHub repository as a branch protected rule, and "Everyone" is selected
    When a user imports this repository to GitLab
    Then "Allowed to force push" will be check on in GitLab protected branches settings
```

## Technical details

Get branch protection rules from [Github API](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/branches/branch-protection#get-branch-protection). Look at `allow_force_pushes` and put it's value into `project.protected_branches` `allow_force_push` attribute.

**Note**: previously we decided to use the strictest set of branch protection rules (in [this issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/22650)). So, if the imported protected branch is also protected in GitLab, we will apply the strictest rule for the `allow_force_push` attribute.

epic.title: Import GitHub rules for protected branches

title: Migrate cadence start date to automation start date
description:
The `start_date` attribute of an Iterations Cadence used to indicate the date on which its first iteration started. After #367493, the attribute stores the date on which the user updated automatic scheduling by setting `automatic` attribute to `true` or changing the automation-related fields.

We should perform a data migration to appropriately set the `start_date` attribute of the existing Iterations Cadence records.

description:

there is a link in the email which has its html escaped

the link's html should not be escaped in the email

| current email |

call `.html_safe` on the link [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/057e6410cbdc20e91812d66eb7bcec52243877b1/ee/app/views/notify/merge_commits_csv_email.html.haml#L3)

title: FE: Add "Last login date" to Billable members list UI
description:
### Problem to solve

There is no way to view the Last Login Date of your billable members on .com (either through the GUI or via the API)

### Proposal

* Add a Last Login Date field to the Seats tab on the Usage quotas page at the namespace (URL: https://gitlab.com/groups/GROUPNAME/-/usage_quotas#seats-quota-tab)
* Use "Last login" as the table header for the user last login date
* Add "Last login" to the [sorting options](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/cfaf8486f02b0d2c4593d2e42e0262b55f291bf7/ee/app/assets/javascripts/usage_quotas/seats/constants.js#L60-77) 

**Note:** adding Last Login Date to the Group Member API is being handled via https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370929

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### Further details

Since we don't allow Admin access on .com, Group administrators need a good way to view the Last Login Date of members in their group. 

### Permissions and Security

Group owners should be able to see the page with this column 

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Group Owners on gitlab.com are able to view their user's Last Login Date.

### What is the type of buyer? 

This should be a Core feature. Everyone on .com should be able to effectively manage users in their Group.

## Designs

See UX issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370931+

## Feature metrics

Tracking usage of feature by usage of sorting by `Last login`: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/377388+

title: BE: Add "Last login date" to Billable Members API
description:
### Problem to solve

There is no way to view the Last Login Date of your group members on .com (either through the GUI or via the API)

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### Further details

Since we don't allow Admin access on .com, Group administrators need a good way to view the Last Login Date of members in their group. [Currently](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/members.html#list-all-billable-members-of-a-group), you can sort by `oldest_sign_in` and `recent_sign_in`, but it doesn't show the actual date of the login.

### Proposal

* Add Last Login Date to the Group Member API 
* Add a Last Login Date field to the Seats tab on the Usage quotas page (not in scope for this issue, being handled via https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370930+)

### Permissions and Security

I believe the 'oldest_sign_in` and `recent_sign_in` is currently restricted to the Admin API, but it would make sense to add it to the Group Member API as well.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Group Owners on gitlab.com are able to view their user's Last Login/signin Date.

### What is the type of buyer? 

This should be a Core feature. Everyone on .com should be able to effectively manage users in their Group.

### Development Notes

**NOTE** that `last_sign_in_at` is not the last time the user logged in.  That is `current_sign_in_at`.  `last_sign_in_at` holds the previous value of `current_sign_in_at`.

### Availability & Testing

title: Add members.member_namespace_id foreign key constraint
description:
As part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/6473 we are replacing the polymorphic relationship between the `members` table and the `projects` and `namespaces` table, with a `members.member_namespace_id` attribute. 

The old relationship was:

```mermaid
graph TD
  User --- Member
  Member-- polymorphic source ---Project
  Member-- polymorphic source ---Namespace
  Namespace-- is a ---Group
```

The new relationships are:

```mermaid
graph TD
  User --- Member
  Member-- member_namespace_id ---Namespace
  Namespace-- is a ---ProjectNamespace
  Namespace-- is a ---Group
  ProjectNamespace --- Project
```

We need to add a foreign key constraint to `members.member_namespace_id` to ensure that a member record always links to a namespace record.

However, on .com there is currently a collection of invalid `members` records, where `members.member_namespace_id IS NULL`. These results are `NULL` because the source `Project` or `Namespace` no longer exist. These associations broke because there was no foreign key constraint on the polymorphic source relationship.

```
gitlabhq_production=> select source_type, count(*), min(updated_at), max(updated_at) from members where member_namespace_id IS NULL GROUP BY source_type;
 source_type | count |            min             |            max
-------------+-------+----------------------------+----------------------------
 Project     |    81 | 2014-11-21 13:38:26.821757 | 2022-06-29 09:29:13.677169
 Namespace   |   443 | 2017-11-06 20:16:52.697449 | 2020-05-07 04:03:51.244068
(2 rows)
```

Before we create a foreign key constraint we will need to remove these records. Then we can add the `members.member_namespace_id` foreign key constraint.

epic.title: Part 1 - Build foundations to consolidate memberships

title: Adjust security report models and ingestion for schema 15-0-0
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work
<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/363134 we'll release version `15-0-0` of the security report schemas.

The following [changes were flagged](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/363134#note_1066531789) as requiring an update on the Rails side:

- Remove `vulnerabilities[].confidence`. Confidence is marked as a required field on both the application layer and the database layer.
- Remove `vulnerabilities[].scanner`. We are currently using this property in `security/common.rb` while parsing the report and genarating the plain old ruby objects. The current logic fails if this property does not exist.

While the properties above are no longer present in `15-0-0`, they are still allowed in `14-x-x` schemas. For each property, we need to either:

1. Completely remove it in %15.4; OR
2. Make it optional in %15.4 and remove them in %16.0 (create separate issue for removal if this path is chosen)

## Relevant links

-->


## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [ ] Documentation:

- [ ] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:


## Implementation plan
- MR 1: Make `confidence` optional
  - [x] [Model](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/1a3155600532fd89b271025acfbce58d7f06b6dc/ee/app/models/vulnerabilities/finding.rb#L71)
  - [x] Add DB migration to make column optional/nullable
- MR 2: mark `confidence` field as deprecated
  - [x] `VulnerabilityCreate` mutation `ee/app/graphql/mutations/vulnerabilities/create.rb`
  - [x] `VulnerabilityConfidenceEnum` `ee/app/graphql/types/vulnerability_confidence_enum.rb`
  - [x] `PipelineSecurityReportFinding` type `ee/app/graphql/types/pipeline_security_report_finding_type.rb`
  - [x] `Vulnerability` REST API `ee/lib/ee/api/entities/vulnerability.rb`
  - [x] `VulnerabilityFindings` REST API `ee/lib/api/vulnerability_findings.rb`
- MR 3: make `confidence` optional for security report parsing
  - [x] `create_finding` in `lib/gitlab/ci/parsers/security/common.rb`

The `scanner` property will be handled in a separate issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/371570.

title: Dismissing page-level alert leaves extra whitespace above breadcrumb
description:
When dismissing a page level alert, there was extra white space left above the breadcrumb. This issue is to investigate the cause to determine whether it was an implementation or component problem.

| Alert | Dismissed |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/639dd329dbdf403526745b8b9f9c0fcc/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/ede4a901e11e36a42f80f53452d64038/image.png) |

MR where this was found: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/94884

Relevant comment: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/94884#note_1065259707

---

## Outcome

During the investigation, we found that the problem is due to some padding that was added to the container: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/4805effd7c919e79df87733138ece0c009788473/ee/app/components/namespaces/free_user_cap/shared.rb#L9.

The alert being the only element inside the wrapper, removing it makes its container empty but preserves the custom padding, which results in the extra space at the top.

## Possible solutions

- Remove the padding from the container, add margin to the alert instead.

title: Securely connect GitLab Web IDE to Remote VM/Container
description:
## Goal

As a follow-up to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368630+, we want to let our users configure their VM/container entirely outside of GitLab and just focus on getting the Web IDE to connect securely, hence being able to side-step us doing any installation/configuration of project dependencies.

## Requirements

- We assume that an end-user has a container/VM running and they want to connect it to the GitLab Web IDE.
- Provide the user with a script that will download and run a VS Code server in their container/VM, and output a GitLab WebIDE URL and a password.
- This URL will contain parameters like the hostname of the VM(in the case of containers, we'd need to figure out some more networking items) and the port of the VS Code server.
- The user will click on the link and in the browser, the user will enter the password(connection token with which the VS code server was started) and the GitLab WebIDE will be instantiated with the above parameters. 

These are **not** part of the Spike:

- Advanced IDE features like linting unless we have the ability to install extensions in the RDE. 

## Success criteria

- Hello world output.

## Results

N/A

title: Add workhorse acceleration for RPM upload route
description:
## Proposal

We are adding support for RPM packages in the package registry. A new upload path is being added: `POST /api/v4/projects/<project_id>/packages/rpm/<filename>`. 

We need to add route handling to workhorse similar to what we have for the other package types ([example](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/ee513ee6b441894c0d68bc96d8891f547a45e7a2/workhorse/internal/upstream/routes.go#L272)).

epic.title: RPM Package Manager MVC

title: RPM Authentication/Authorization
description:
## Proposal

Add authentication to the two RPM API endpoints created in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370867. We should use the `API::Helpers::Authentication` module, similar to how we have implemented this in [NuGet](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/dd1e70d3676891025534dc4a1e89ca9383178fe7/lib/api/nuget_group_packages.rb#L20).

We should accept:

- Personal access tokens
- Deploy tokens
- Job tokens

Sent through:

- Basic Auth

The POST/PUT endpoints should always require authentication.

The GET endpoints should only require authentication when the project is not public.

[Authorization](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/policies.html) should be checked for the given project using `:read_package` and `:create_package` permissions.

epic.title: RPM Package Manager MVC

title: RPM API skeleton
description:
## Proposal

Add an initial set of [grape APIs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/api_styleguide.html) behind a [development feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/) scoped to projects for RPM.

### Endpoints needed

1. `GET api/v4/project/<project_id>/packages/rpm/<package_file_id>/<filename>` - Download RPM package files
1. `GET api/v4/project/<project_id>/packages/rpm/repodata/<filename>` - Download repository metadata files
2. `POST api/v4/project/<project_id>/packages/rpm/<filename>` - Upload RPM package files
3. `POST api/v4/project/<project_id>/packages/rpm/<filename>/authorize` - workhorse accelerated upload authorization. Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370869.

In this issue we are not concerned with functionality, but with defining the endpoints and adding the ~"feature flag" scoped to projects for use throughout the development of RPM. All endpoints should return `404`.

title: Rename Child widget to Tasks for MVC and update the Add button & help copy to reflect this
description: ## Context Following up on conversation here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369882#note_1057880373 In our first iteration of `Child items` there are a few challenges: - Only `Tasks` are displayed and addable within this widget - There is no clear open/close `Task` icon or validated way to display this status separated from indictor of work item type (used to be an open/close icon) - There is no clear way to indicate type of item within this widget and `issue type` icons are receiving feedback and may need to be iterated on. - To the above point, there are only tasks in this widget anyway meaning it should be clearly labeled as such. - We currently rely on the `Add a task` button to demonstrate type when clearer labeling would be the preferred solution. ## Solution 1. Change the title of this widget from [-Child items-] to [+Tasks+] (for now) until we add other types to this widget and sort out some of the above challenges 1. Change that [-Add a task-] button labeling to just [+Add+] as it is now clear what the user is adding based on label alone. 1. Change help text copy from: {-No child items are currently assigned. Use child items to prioritize tasks that your team should complete in order to accomplish your goals!-} to {+No tasks are currently assigned. Use tasks to break down the goal of this issue into smaller parts.+}

title: Tidy up caching diffs_batch cache
description:
To finish tidying up the caching, we need to:

1. Remove the etag feature flag (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369488)
1. Investigate whether or not to remove the caching completely

The second relies on us having more information on the usefulness of it, to do this we will reintroduce a feature flag to check the performance impact (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370933), and secondly we have a MR to allow us to see the hit/miss rate (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/94966)

title: Process isolation for customers.gitlab.com
description:
<!--
Triage of infradev Issues is desired to occur asynchronously.
For maximum efficiency, please ensure the following, so that your infradev issues can gain maximum traction.

https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/workflow/#a-guide-to-creating-effective-infradev-issues
-->

## Summary
<!--
Clearly state the scope of the problem, and how it affects GitLab.com
-->

We've had several incidents where the processes on `customers-01-inf-prdsub` were starving for CPU or memory because one process on the box consumed all resources.

Most recently:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/7589
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/7263


## Impact
<!--
- Quantify the effect of the problem to help ensure that correct prioritization occurs.
- Include costs to availability. The Incident Budget Explorer dashboard can help here.
- Include the number of times alerts have fired owing to the problem, how much time was spent dealing with the problem, and how many people were involved.
- Link to affected incidents, and cross-reference them as related issues.
- Include screenshots of visualization from Grafana or Kibana.
- Always include a permalink to the source of the screenshot so that others can investigate further.
-->

When this happens, customers.gitlab.com becomes unavailable.


## Recommendation
<!--
Provide a clear, unambiguous, self-contained solution to the problem.
-->

`customers-01-inf-prdsub` hosts many different processes related to the customers service, including postgres, puma, and sidekiq workers.

We should isolate these processes to avoid any single one from consuming unlimited amounts of CPU or memory.

This can be done by applying cgroup limits on the systemd units. The [systemd resource control](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.resource-control.html) parameters we can use are: `CPUQuota`, `MemoryMax`.

## Verification
<!--
Provide a method for validating that the original issue still exists.

Having a way of checking validity can save on a great deal of back-and-forth discussion between Infradev Triage participants including Engineering Managers, Directors and Product Managers and make space for other non-resolved issues to get scheduled sooner.

Ideally, provide a link to a Thanos query or an ELK query and clear instructions on how to interpret the results to determine whether the problem is still occurring.
-->

It's a little difficult to verify, since this only impacts the service when one process starts consuming too many resources. It should be possible to simulate that situation though.

<!--
Workflow and other relevant labels

See also:
- https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/issue-triage/#availability
- https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/categories/
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/blob/master/data/stages.yml
-->

title: Update translations levels (September 2022)
description:
## Introduction

With the implementation of the feature to show the [translation coverage](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328430) in the language selection dropdown, the translation levels need to be updated on a monthly cadence. 

## Proposal

Once the monthly merge of the new translations is complete, update the translation levels [data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/i18n.rb#L43) from Crowdin.

## Documentation

* https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/i18n/merging_translations.html#manually-update-the-translation-levels

#### ToDo
* [x] After cloning: update Title, set Milestone, Due date (15th), Related to previous month's issue.
* [x] After the 1st of the month: assign to yourself, set ~2526320 
* [x] Complete the [regular monthly merge](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3571) of translations from Crowdin.
* [x] Get the translation levels (% approved words) from [Crowdin](https://crowdin.com/project/gitlab-ee).
* [x] Create an MR to update the translation levels [data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/i18n.rb#L43).
* [x] Associate that MR to this issue.
* [ ] Complete the MR.
* [x] When done, clone [this template issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/349815) for the next milestone.

description:

title: Investigate: Process webhook notifications for tag delete and create events
description:
### Context

The epic https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8213+ proposes adding user-level data for the GitLab Container Registry. This data would help drive prioritization and investment in the Container Registry category.

The high-level plan for delivering this was outlined in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/364730#note_1058520288. This specific issue is part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/9234+, which targets the "Process" stage of the outlined implementation plan.

## Task - Investigation

As described in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/364730#note_1058520288, the first step is to process the already emitted (by the registry) and consumed (by Rails) registry webhook notifications for tag delete/create requests. This needs to be done on the Rails side.

These notifications already include the type of event, the target container repository, and the username. So they have all that Rails needs to consume and increment the respective (new) counters to track usage.

This issue is meant to be an **investigation** on how to implement the collection and processing of these events on the ~rails side to increment (new) counters for usage tracking.

The end goal is to count the number of users that have created or deleted container registry tags. It should be possible to aggregate these counters by month and week, so that we can know how many distinct users created/deleted tags per month and week.

For scalability reasons, this should likely be implemented with Redis counters, similar to how it was done for package registry events in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/275942+. Since this was done a few years ago, we should make sure this is still the best option. We should also involve Product Analysts in this conversation (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/364730#note_1027217479).

epic.title: Container Registry AMAU - Process data
